NEWS.TITLE: Arirang [Traditional Music]
NEWS.TEXT:
[Ŀ] Turning back to Arirang, the type of music most people associate with Korea these days is likely that by Psy and other K-pop artists. But as Kim Ji-yeon now reports, there is much more than that to the music scene here.
[Ʈ] You're listening to gugak,... traditional Korean music that has been passed down through the generations.
This performance at Changgyeong Palace in central Seoul features the 76-year-old Master Lee Saeng-gang, who has been a musician almost all his life.
He is recognized as a living national treasure for his role in preserving traditional Korean music.
[Interview] Yi Saeng-gahng / 'Daegeum' player "What I love most about gugak is that the depth of the music is endless. Although I've dedicated almost my entire life to playing the daeguem, I feel that there's so much more to learn. The moment I start playing, I can feel the warmth and humanity of our Korean ancestors and their efforts to express it in their rhythms and music."
His instrument is the daegeum, a flute made of bamboo that is believed to have been invented sometime between 681 and 692.
With six openings in the front and one in the back, the daegeum has a buzzing membrane that gives it a special timbre.
[Interview] Choi Mi-na / Listener "One of my wishes was to hear gugak up close. Now that I'm here at the royal palace to see Master Lee Saeng-gang in performance, it's wonderful. It's something that you don't often get to do. I hope I can see more gugak performances in the future."
Master Lee's wish is to get more Koreans to fall in love with gugak as he has... and to spread the beauty of Korean traditional music to the international community.
His wish has been answered in part by a group of young Koreans who formed a band that incorporates traditional gugak instruments and the sounds of contemporary rock.
[Interview] Choi Yoon-sang / Leader of wHOOL "We came up with the idea of mixing traditional and modern elements, so that a global audience of Koreans and non-Koreans can learn more about Korea and the beauty of our music. The most memorable moment was when we were playing at the South African World Cup back in 2010. The local people there absolutely loved our fusion music."
[Arirang News] Kim Ji-yeon "Whether traditional or modern,...Korean artists young and old are trying to spread the beauty of gugak to the international community.
Kim Ji-yeon, Arirang News."

NEWS.TITLE: KCTV [Struggling 20s ]
NEWS.TEXT:
[Ŀ] University students are really feeling the pinch these days, as they struggle to pay for tuition, housing, food, and other expenses while at the same time work to keep their grades up. Here's Mike Balfour with more.
[Ʈ] (ȣ) Ko Dae-ho, a student, is a part-time worker at a convenience store. He has been at the job for a year and a half. He needs the money. It is tiring juggling both studying and a part-time job, but to pay university expenses he has no choice but to work, even on the weekend.
< Interview : Ko Dae-ho >
This student is junior in college and does part-time work at an internet cafe every weekend. She works 8 hours a day and gets paid 320,000 won. As she lives apart from her family, she has to work, even during the school term, to meet her rent and living expenses.
< Interview >
In April, Democratic Party congresswoman (ϳ) Jang Ha-na, the Jeju Youth Union Association and student councils of three universities in Jeju conducted a survey on conditions of part-time working.
Of the more than 1000 local university respondents, 8 out of 10 students have worked as part-timer.
### CG IN ### Most of them have no choice but to find part-time work to pay for their education costs and pay off their student debt.
Wages earned are spent thusly: 31% for housing, 27% for food, 12% for transportation and 10% for communications charges. Therefore 80% of part-time wages go to living expenses alone. ### CG OUT ###
The low wages only allow the students to get by, they cannot invest in their future.
< Interview : Yoo Byeong-seon >
Education expenses are becoming increasingly burdensome to youth in their 20's. Their thoughts of the future focus on financial problems rather than dreams.
Mike Balfour KCTV.

The Chujado Yellow Corvina Festival starts Saturday.

NEWS.TITLE: JPDC signs contract to export Samdasoo and Hallasoo to China
NEWS.TEXT:
Economy
JPDC signs contract to export Samdasoo and Hallasoo to China
CJ O Shopping agrees to ship 120,000 tons by 2017
Two locally bottled water products, Jeju Samdasoo and (Ѷ) Hallasoo, will be exported to China through CJ O Shopping.
The Jeju Provincial Development Corporation signed a contract to that effect with CJ O Shopping, which agreed to ship 120,000 tons of water worth 500 billion won to home shopping channels, large retailers, and department stores in China by the year 2017.
The JPDC is aiming to export 15,000 tons of water this year, which is four times as much as last year. It is also being shipped to more countries - last year it was exported to seven, but this year it will be sent to 14.

NEWS.TITLE: Arirang [Family Reunions? ]
NEWS.TEXT:
[Ŀ] Turning to Arirang now, there had been high hopes this week's now-canceled inter-Korean talks would have led to the resumption of reunions for families separated by the Korean War. Those hopes seem to have been dashed, at least temporarily, by the breakdown in communications between Seoul and Pyongyang. Here's Arirang's Song Ji-sun () with the stories of some of the reunion applicants here in the South.
[Ʈ]
These senior citizens hoped to meet their family members north of the border at the next family reunion.
It could've been held as soon as the fall... but as the scheduled inter-Korean talks never materialized, they can't be sure how much longer they must wait.
[Interview] Park Deok-pil (74) / Relatives live in North Korea "We just heard the news on Wednesday... and it was so disappointing. I've already tried other ways of keeping in contact with my family in North Korea -- I once even passed a letter to an American envoy entering Pyongyang, hoping it'd be delivered."
The last reunions for separated families were held in November 2010. The clock is ticking for people hoping to see their families one last time,... as four out of five applicants are 70-years-old or older.
Nearly half of those who applied for reunions... have already passed away. Given the circumstances, age is a major criteria when candidates are selected.
Older applicants whose family members have been confirmed as alive in the North are given first priority.
But there are other options available. These include exchanging video or written letters through unofficial channels... and arranging reunions in a third country.
The South Korean Unification Ministry subsidizes the travel expenses for people who choose the latter,.. but people say it's not an easy option.
[Interview] Cho Sook-ja (78) / Brother lives in North Korea "It's not easy for us to afford the trip, nor will it be easy for us to travel at our age. But we want to know whether our families are alive, and where they are now."
Seoul's immediate goal... is to establish a regular cycle of reunions.
[Interview] Kim Seong-keun / Korean Red Cross "The family members who have been separated are old.. and about 3 to 4-thousand applicants die each year without getting to meet their families one last time. So the most important thing is to set up a system that allows these elderly separated family members to reunite with their families on a regular basis."
[Arirang News] Song Ji-sun
But in order for that to happen, the two Koreas must meet for talks so they can work out the details.
Song Ji-sun, Arirang News.

NEWS.TITLE: Ideas sought for new school's name
NEWS.TEXT:
Education
Ideas sought for new school's name
Elementary school will open in the Samwha District next March
The provincial office of education is seeking the public's suggestions for the name of the elementary school that will open in the (ȭ) Samhwa District next March.
The temporarily-named (ȭ) Samhwa 2 Elementary School sits on over 13,000 square meters of land. It will have 24 classes of students to accommodate children who live in the district.
Anyone with an idea on what to name the institution can email the suggestion to the Jeju City Office of Education or drop it off in person by July 12th.
Officials are accepting submissions from all local residents, be they children or adults. Everyone who does send in an idea will have a chance at winning a 50,000-won gift certificate that will be raffled off.

NEWS.TITLE: New off-limits areas for motorized watercraft
NEWS.TEXT:
Society
New off-limits areas for motorized watercraft
Coast guard bans them from within 10 meters of safety lines at 7 beaches
In order to minimize the risk of accidents, the Jeju Coast Guard has banned the operation of motorized watercraft in areas around seven local beaches.
The seven beaches are () Hyupjae, (ȣ׿) Iho Taewu, () Gwakji Gwamul, (ݴ) Geumneung Euddeumwon, (缺) Gimnyeong Seongsegi, (Դ) Hamdeok Seowubong and Samyang Blacksand Beach.
Anyone riding a motor boat or jetski may do so when the beaches are open, but they may not come within ten meters of the safety lines floating in the water at them. Violators will be fined up to one million won.

NEWS.TITLE: South Koreans name Jeju top domestic vacation spot
NEWS.TEXT:
Tourism
South Koreans name Jeju top domestic vacation spot
Results of 2012 national survey released
According to a survey, visitors to the island are very pleased with their stays here.
The national survey was conducted last year, but the results were only recently released. Respondents thought highly of the island's natural landscape, cultural heritage sites, transportation, accommodations, tourism information, facilities, and friendliness. They were also pleased that the island was not overcrowded.
Jeju topped the lists of destinations people would most like to visit again and which they would most highly recommend to others.
It wasn't all good news though, as the island only ranked third in terms of available activities. Some view that as a disappointment, because it had been number one in 2011.

NEWS.TITLE: 'Jeju needs to be seen as premium vacation spot'
NEWS.TEXT:
Administration
'Jeju needs to be seen as premium vacation spot'
IBM Smarter Cities Challenge team releases preliminary report
Experts say it's important for Jeju to create an image of itself as a premium vacation destination and as a producer of high value-added goods.
The project team for Jeju's IBM Smarter Cities Challenge made five recommendations to develop the island based on its analysis of current conditions. The team outlined those ideas Thursday morning at the provincial office.
The recommendations include attracting tourists for specific purposes, developing Jeju's image as an island that makes premium products, the digitization of more tourist information to give prospective visitors a better online idea of what Jeju has to offer, and getting small companies to work more in tandem.
The provincial government says it will come up with detailed measures in response to IBM's final recommendations, which will be unveiled around August.

NEWS.TITLE: Jeju International Wind Ensemble Festival begins August 8
NEWS.TEXT:
Culture
Jeju International Wind Ensemble Festival begins August 8
3,000+ participants from 28 countries expected
The Jeju International Wind Ensemble Festival will begin August 8th at the Jeju Seaside Concert Hall and other venues.
The festival's organizing committee says over 3,000 people will participate this year. Among the 28 countries that will be represented are Germany, Hungary, France, and, of course, South Korea.
The opening ceremony for the event will be at 3:00 p.m. on the 8th at the Jeju Culture and Art Center. It will be followed by a street parade, and then the Jeju Brass Competition, special concerts, and concert tours will run through August 16th.
Organizers began last year to hold the Jeju Brass Competition and the Band Festival concurrently. Until 2011 each one had been held on its own every other year.
